Award.AwardTitle: Polarization Quantum Beat Spectroscopy in Diatomic Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this scientific project, energy transfer processes in collisions between atoms and molecules are investigated. These processes play an important role and are essential to the understanding of combustion dynamics, astrophysical plasmas and plasma formation. The results can serve as bench marks with which to verify theoretical models of the processes. Theoretical models are themselves useful because they may be then conveniently applied to physical systems that are more difficult or more expensive to study experimentally. The amount of energy transfer arising from collisions between atoms and molecules will be studied by using two lasers. First, the internal properties of the quantum states of molecules will be manipulated by a laser beam. These molecules then oscillate like vibrating violin strings and collisions can alter their quantum properties. A second probe laser will arrive at the system after some time delay and sense this alteration. By varying the delay time between the two lasers as short as 10 picoseconds, time evolution of the molecular properties can be mapped out, similar to the way a stroboscope maps out the motion of macroscopic objects. These studies can provide exceptional spectroscopic precision and understanding of the various transfer processes.

This project provides understanding of energy transfer processes that are important in combustion and plasma formation. It has an essential and socially important educational aspect as well. This project integrates research components into course work at Miami University while providing students with hands-on laboratory experience with state-of-the-art technology. The extensive research training and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students contribute to the future professionals entering science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research group of Burcin Bayram in the Physics Department at Miami University (Ohio) carried out a series of fundamental studies of coherent light-matter interactions using lasers, diatomic molecules and the ideas of quantum physics. Her group investigated radiative and collisional relaxation and energy transfer processes by measuring the light emitted from excited atoms and molecules of sodium, cesium and iodine. This work contributes to a better understanding of atomic and molecular dynamics, combustion dynamics, and plasma formation. In addition this work is likely to enrich and benefit the development of novel solar energy devices and/or the design of photochemical reactions.

 

This project has made contributions to the field of precise measurements of atomic and molecular parameters. These parameters are essential to provide benchmark values that can be used to assess the reliability of theoretical methodologies. Bayram’s group studied time-dependent polarization quantum beats, multiple moments such as alignment, decay fluorescence, and collisional cross section using a pump-probe excitation scheme. With this approach, energetically high-energy atomic or molecular levels were accessed while an approach based on optical double resonance provided convenient light emission pathways to serve as signals for detection of the various processes.

 

This project provided undergraduate and graduate students, at Miami University, with a unique opportunity to be engaged in experimental atomic, molecular and optical physics research.  Students have learned about many experimental techniques, including time-resolved pump-probe spectroscopy, laser-induced fluorescence, quantum beat spectroscopy, and molecular spectroscopy. They gained high-level scientific and technical hands-on laboratory experiences and as a result developed confidence for their future involvement in the STEM workforce. Students attended national, regional and undergraduate-focused symposia at professional conferences to present their research findings. The success observed in students for this hands-on work has encouraged the principal investigator to integrate parts of this project into an advanced laboratory courses, and to develop exciting physics demonstrations which were presented to the broader community. New experiments for advance laboratory instruction and educational materials were created and disseminated in pedagogical journals and at the national education conferences.
